thread.title: World War II fighter pilot Bob Cowper 'made Biggles look like a wimp'
thread.title_full: World War II fighter pilot Bob Cowper 'made Biggles look like a wimp'

title: World War II fighter pilot Bob Cowper 'made Biggles look like a wimp'
text:
Map: Adelaide 5000 
One of Australia's most decorated World War II fighter aces has been fittingly farewelled with a flyover at a funeral service at Adelaide's Morphettville Racecourse. 
Former squadron leader and fighter pilot Bob Cowper died at his home last week, only days short of his 94th birthday. 
Mr Cowper was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross (with bar) for gallantry, and the French Legion of Honour for his role in the D-Day invasion at Normandy in 1944. 
He also received the Medal of the Order of Australia in 2012. 
"[His life] reads like something straight out of a Captain WE Johns novel," the RSL's Bill Denny told those gathered for the funeral service. 
"However, having read a couple of those, I'd have to say Bob's exploits make Biggles look like something of a wimp!" 
The service was attended by family, friends, veterans and dignitaries including Governor Hieu Van Le. 
Among the eulogies was a reading by great-grandaughter Alyce Harvey, of a poem Mr Cowper wrote for his late wife Kay on her 76th birthday. 
"Thank you for all the love for these many years," Ms Harvey read. 
"We've had lots of laughs and very few tears." Bob Cowper's great escape 
Born in Broken Hill in 1922, Mr Cowper grew up in Kangaroo Flat outside Gawler and enlisted in the RAAF in 1940 on his 18th birthday. Photo: Servicemen carry the coffin of former squadron leader and fighter pilot Bob Cowper. (ABC News) 
During the war he flew Defiants, Beaufighters and Mosquitoes over Britain, Malta and France, and survived several very close shaves during 68 aerial missions. 
Perhaps the closest of all was plummeting through the night sky while unconscious, after shooting down an enemy plane. 
The enemy aircraft exploded with such force it sent his own aircraft into a spiral, forcing him to bail out. 
Mr Cowper lost consciousness, but regained it just in time to open his parachute. 
"I remember putting my hand down to see if my parachute was still there," he told the ABC in 2007, the year his autobiography was published. 
"I pulled the rip cord and the parachute opened. 
"I must have travelled a fair way down, because it was only a matter of a few seconds, almost, and I was in the sea." 
On another occasion Mr Cowper's plane, which was carrying top secret radar, crash-landed in the Sahara Desert but the crew was rescued by a local tribe. 
In 1944, he became flight commander of 456 Squadron and also earned the title of 'ace', bestowed on pilots who shot down at least five enemy aircraft. 
He destroyed six, damaged another and also claimed co-credit for destroying a V-1 flying bomb. 
Mr Cowper and Kay were married for almost 70 years, with Kay giving birth to the first of several children before the conflict was over. 
On his return home, he lived on the land, trained racehorses and represented veterans. 
"Most of the ones that we killed, shooting down in their aircraft, were young fellows doing what they were told by monsters," he said in 2012.
